Exactly. Suppose we do count them in our equilibrium expression. A(s) + [B](g) -> C(s) + D(g) We will﻿ get K = [D][C]/[A][B] if we include both solids. However, since concentration of these guys remains at 1 (by assumption), one to the any power will always give us 1. Therefore, we can take them away.
Yes. That helped some, So on #2 are you saying that the concentrations of liquids and solids stay the same all throughout the reaction so they are not a good determiner of equilibrium?
Let me know if that better explains your questions.
** [pure solid] = [pure liquid] = 1 Molar for equilibrium expressions.
expressions. Therefore, when you try plugging in the concentration for either solid or liquid, you get (1) raised to some power, which will always give you one.

I am happy to know that you are using my videos to help you study! Sorry for the late response but I have been away. Anyways  1) The only way you really know if a reaction is elementary is if you are told so. Otherwise, there is really no way of knowing this. Absolutely not. The law of mass action (the equilibrium constant, K) applies to both elementary as well as complex reactions.  2) Basically, the concentration of a pure solid or liquid is usually assumed to be 1 Molar for equilibirum

I don't understand how density would exclude them.  Thanks in advanced. :)
